biography: CO— is here to help you start, run and grow your business.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by CO— by USCC on August 17, 2021. May be an image of 1 person.

node.text:
"Clicks are currency."⁠
⁠
That's an e-commerce mantra we picked up from @robertombraven, a coach for Google's @digitalcoachesprogram in Los Angeles. ⁠
⁠
Martinez says the best way to increase online sales is by “optimizing your online presence for clicks.” Business owners can do this by making it as easy as possible for customers to click through their online channels including blogs, social media and web pages.⁠
⁠
In short: Clicks = $ (either $ spent or $ earned)⁠
⁠
“The easier it is and the least amount of steps it takes for the customer to make a purchase, the better,” explained Martinez. “On the web, clicks are ‘steps’ ... so, if we cut down on the steps to buy, the more likely the customer is to buy.”⁠
⁠
Amazon, for example, has a one-click option for customers to make their purchase immediately.⁠
⁠
“The more clicks a customer has to take to buy on your website, the less likely they are to continue on their journey,” emphasized Martinez.⁠
⁠
Additionally, he said, fewer clicks mean less money spent on paid ads that charge per click, depending on the industry. These savings give a business the chance to grow and use the extra money to continue driving online traffic.⁠
⁠
“Less is more,” said Martinez. “The less clicks, the more likely you are to sell.”⁠
⁠
Read more about finding the right click to sales ratio at your business at the link in our bio.⁠
⁠

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by CO— by USCC on August 12, 2021 tagging @curecrate. May be an image of 1 person, standing, outdoors and text that says 'all'.

node.text:
What’s the secret to business success? ⁠
⁠
For Alexandra Mulconnery, CEO of personalized CBD subscription service @curecrate, the key has been letting go of perfection. ⁠
⁠
“There’s always a push between perfecting your work and making progress quickly,” Mulconnery told us. “While I’m the first to want to get everyone’s feedback to try and perfect something, it’s important to remember that you’ll never please everyone and will surely run into conflicting advice.”⁠
⁠
Instead, trying, failing quickly and constantly iterating will likely get you a lot further, quicker. ⁠
⁠
“As an entrepreneur, you have to trust yourself and get comfortable with things being less than perfect,” she added.⁠
⁠
Mulconnery co-founded Cure Crate with her business partner Sean Wynn in 2020. After attending numerous CBD product release parties, Mulconnery was ready to put her own spin on the increasingly popular wellness benefits of CBD: personalized care. ⁠
⁠
“The main things I learned along this path are that no one person is the same, and while we all deserve to have expert guidance, ultimately you should be empowered to choose what works best for you and adjust as needed over time,” Mulconnery told CO—. ⁠
⁠
Read more about Cure Crate at the link in our bio.

buttons.text: Visit the COVID-19 Information Center for vaccine resources.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by CO— by USCC on August 11, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says '"A vaccinated workforce is a safer workforce." -Tom West, deputy assistant secretary, U.S. Treasury Department's Office of Tax Policy CO-'.

node.text:
We talk a lot about strategies for incentivizing customers to return to your business, but today we want to talk about an incentive designed for you, the small business owner: The tax credit for employers offering paid time off for vaccinations.⁠
⁠
Earlier this year, the Biden administration signed the American Rescue Plan (ARP) into law. Through the ARP, small and medium-sized employers who offered employees time off for vaccinations could qualify for a tax credit. ⁠
⁠
Recently, the Biden administration extended this vaccine tax credit to include family members of employees, explained Tom West, who is the deputy assistant secretary of the @treasurydept's Office of Tax Policy and who joined us at our Small Business Update virtual event on Monday (8/9).⁠
⁠
What does this extension of the tax credit mean? Employees can take time off to help members of their household receive and recover from the vaccine, and employers can receive a tax credit for offering that time.⁠
⁠
“This is all about incentivizing employers to give time off to employees to handle the COVID situation,” said West. “Employers are also benefiting because … their employees aren’t infecting other people. … and a vaccinated workforce is a safer workforce.”⁠
⁠
At Monday's event, we also took audience questions about @sbagov's new PPP loan forgiveness portal, which @uschamber's Chief Policy Officer, Neil Bradley, summed up as follows:⁠
⁠
“It’s kind of like [going] to the EZ Pass lane. If it says you’re approved, you don’t have to go back and get all of this extra paperwork.”⁠
⁠
Watch a replay of our event and read the key takeaways at the link in our bio. ⁠

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by CO— by USCC on August 09, 2021 tagging @treasurydept, and @sbagov. May be an image of text that says 'SMALL BUSINESS UPDATE August 9,2021, Ipm ET'.

node.text:
Don't miss our Small Business Update today at 1pm ET!⁠
⁠
We'll be joined by @uschamber EVP & Chief Policy Officer Neil Bradley, as well as Tom West, Deputy Assistant Secretary for @treasurydept's Office of Tax Policy. ⁠
⁠
As always, our editor-in-chief Jeanette Mulvey will moderate the discussion and glean insights on what recent updates to federal policies and programs mean for small businesses. ⁠
⁠
Today, we'll dive deep into two main topics: ⁠
+ New employer tax credits to support vaccination efforts ⁠
+ The SBA's new PPP forgiveness portal ⁠
⁠
Have questions about these topics? Bring them with you to our live audience Q&A and get answers from our experts. ⁠
⁠
RSVP now (or tune in) at the link in our bio!

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by CO— by USCC on August 05, 2021 tagging @mm_doggieretreat. May be an image of 1 person, dog and outdoors.

node.text:
Customer connection is key — especially when your customers are both human AND canine.⁠
⁠
Louisiana-based small business MaryMac’s Doggie Retreat provides daycare, grooming and boarding services for pups, especially those who are anxious or allergic. ⁠
⁠
“We provide dog owners with an alternative option for their dogs to receive the proper care that caters to their dog’s physical and emotional health,” @mm_doggieretreat founder Courtney McWilliams told us.⁠
⁠
The idea for MaryMac’s first came in 2015, when McWilliams needed a pet sitter for her dog who suffered from separation anxiety.⁠
⁠
Recognizing this niche market with a yet-unmet need, she combined her love of dogs and her background in social work to develop her unique business model.⁠
⁠
The boutique doggy daycare has seen tremendous growth during the pandemic, going from zero clients to 700-plus clients and a waiting list. McWilliams credits this to leveraging the power of social media and understanding the needs of her customer base.⁠
⁠
“From a tactical standpoint, social media has been critical to my growth,” she noted. “I created weekly ad campaigns with a targeted audience and asked my friends to share my ‘Quarantine and Chill’ flyer offering a special for grooming services.”⁠
⁠
But, as previously mentioned, the real key to McWilliams’ success as a business owner stems from the connection she has with pets and their owners. ⁠
⁠
“When dogs are happy, ‘pawrents’ are happy, and that brings in more and more business and success.”⁠
⁠
Read more about @ mm_doggieretreat at the link in our bio.⁠

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by CO— by USCC on August 04, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Small Business News Many employers (and self-employed individuals) will now be able to claim tax credits for wages paid to employees who take time off to accompany or care for family members who get vaccinated. cO-'.

node.text:
⚠️ The federal government has expanded paid leave tax credits to support vaccination efforts. ⚠️⁠
⁠
Many employers will now be able to claim tax credits for wages paid to employees who take time off to accompany or care for family members who get vaccinated. The decision, put forth by the U.S. Treasury Department and IRS, also includes comparable tax credits for the self-employed who face loss of wages in the process of helping loved ones through the vaccination process. ⁠
⁠
The announcement comes months after introducing paid leave tax credits under the American Rescue Plan to mitigate the cost of employees taking personal vaccination-related leave. ⁠
⁠
Get the facts on eligibility and how to claim your tax credits (as well as more information about tax credits for small businesses) at the link in our bio.⁠

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by CO— by USCC on August 03, 2021 tagging @linadarrisaw, @csuitecoach, @libbylivingcolorfully, @thezensucculent, and @rhoback. node.text:
Practice makes perfect... but expert tips can help!⁠
⁠
Learn how to optimize your business's social media strategy at a free virtual event for business owners, this Thursday (8/5) at 12pm ET.⁠
⁠
This interactive panel discussion (with plenty of time for audience questions) will provide guidance on how to choose the best social platforms for your business, how to build an effective content plan and how to optimize the social media strategies that are already working for you!⁠
⁠
You'll hear from small business owners who've built loyal social followings, as well as experts with insights into the best digital tools for social marketing, including...⁠
⁠
⭐ @csuitecoach CEO @linadarrisaw⁠
⁠
⭐ @thezensucculent owner Megan Cain⁠
⁠
⭐ @rhoback co-founder Kevin Hubbard⁠
⁠
⭐ Social media director & digital creator @libbylivingcolorfully ⁠
⁠
RSVP at the link in our bio!⁠

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by CO— by USCC on July 30, 2021 tagging @cheerscreative, and @digitalcoachesprogram. May be an image of 1 person, standing and outdoors.

node.text:
Pssst. We have a secret that can help you grow your business…⁠
⁠
… GET ORGANIZED! ⁠
⁠
It’s as simple as that: In order to scale a company, you really need to have all your ducks in a row, according to @danajamesmwangi, founder of @cheerscreative and a coach for Google’s @digitalcoachesprogram.⁠
⁠
“Organization of every part of your business — including and especially … the structure [and] flow of your services — helps you to know your process inside and out. It also makes you a better and more confident seller ... [which] increases trust, because you sound like an expert.”⁠
⁠
James Mwangi shared four tips to help entrepreneurs organize their internal processes and focus on the right activities to drive lasting growth:⁠
⁠
🦆 Start with organizing and automating your client inquiry process⁠
⁠
🦆 Don’t get caught up in too many choices⁠
⁠
🦆 Develop a consistent brand⁠
⁠
🦆 Focus on income-generating activities⁠
⁠
Read more about how to execute these organizational tips at the link in our bio.⁠

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by CO— by USCC on July 29, 2021 tagging @gothamgreens, @brightfarms, @aerofarms, @boweryfarming, and @localbounti.official. May be an image of 1 person and tomato.

node.text:
Talk about an industry that’s ripe for disruption…⁠
⁠
During the COVID-19 pandemic, commercial indoor farms have been riding a wave of technological innovation and financial investment, as these companies seek to satisfy consumer demand for locally grown produce while at the same time reshaping the nation’s food-supply system.⁠
⁠
Many indoor farms — which focus on using sustainable farming practices to grow leafy vegetables, tomatoes, herbs and berries — supply their crops to local supermarkets and restaurants that promote their produce’s local provenance. ⁠
⁠
The growers say that not only are their products more sustainable than traditionally grown crops that often travel across the country after they are harvested, but they are also less exposed to weather fluctuations and other supply chain disruptions (like those that occurred around the world during the pandemic).⁠
⁠
We recently spoke to founders and experts in the indoor farming industry to unpack the acceleration of indoor farming practices and what they mean for farm-focused startups, restaurants, supermarkets AND consumers.⁠
⁠
Sink your teeth into their insights at the link in our bio. ⁠

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by CO— by USCC on July 27, 2021 tagging @aptive_resources. May be a closeup of 1 person.

node.text:
You wouldn’t run a race without stretching. Why should preparing to grow your business be any different?⁠
⁠
We recently spoke with Rachele Cooper, CEO and founder of @aptive_resources, a government consulting firm located in Alexandria, Virginia, who talked to us about the role that flexibility plays for businesses in growth mode.⁠
⁠
Nimbleness is key, not just in response to COVID but all the time, Cooper said.⁠
⁠
“A culture of continuous learning and open communication enables efficient decision making and supports learning cycles,” said Cooper. “We’ve found that by being agile, we can stabilize the business even through a period of rapid growth.”⁠
⁠
While many businesses may have had to slow down their operations or cease them entirely during the pandemic, Aptive Resources actually grew in employees, contracts and revenue.⁠
⁠
“We added dozens of new government contracts, hired about 100 employees and nearly doubled our revenue,” Cooper said. “All internal systems experienced rapid expansion and maturation.”⁠
⁠
The one thing that did need to change was how Cooper and her employees worked in the new normal with lockdowns and stay-at-home orders. ⁠
⁠
While their office was equipped to handle the change, there were some adjustments that needed to be made. Cooper credits Aptive Resources’ ability to change for its success, especially when it comes to employee pivots.⁠
⁠
“We instituted flexible work schedules so employees could conduct their work in a way that is optimal for their own situations,” explained Cooper. “We [also] shifted our in-person meetings and events to virtual environments. Instead of happy hours, we played online trivia, attended a virtual concert and watched a livestreamed magic show.”⁠
⁠
Aptive Resources also began hiring employees around the country rather than just at its Alexandria office, while providing their staff with the appropriate technology to ensure they could work remotely. ⁠
⁠
Learn more about Cooper’s business journey at the link in our bio.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by CO— by USCC on July 22, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Small Business News New grant competition supports entrepreneurship among minority university and college students cO-'.

node.text:
Want the latest news for small business owners, all in one place? ⁠
⁠
Including timely updates on:⁠
-Taxes⁠
-Grants & Awards⁠
-Events⁠
-Funding ⁠
-Consumer trends⁠
⁠
Look no further than our small business news section, updated regularly with the news you need to run your business. Click the link in our bio to start exploring.⁠
⁠
Here's a sneak peak:⁠
⁠
🗞  New grant competition supports entrepreneurship among minority university and college students⁠
⁠
To advance their mission of nurturing the entrepreneurship that will lead to future innovation and growth, the Minority Business Development Agency (MBDA) is now accepting proposals for pilot programs from undergraduates at minority colleges and universities. One program will be established at each type of minority-centered school including Historically Black Colleges and Universities, Hispanic Serving Institutions, Tribal Colleges & Universities, Native Hawaiian Serving Institutions and Alaska Native Serving Institutions. Deadline to apply is 11:59 PM on August 16th. Register to attend a pre-application virtual information session on August 3. ⁠
⁠
🗞  Mark your calendars with these upcoming tax deadlines⁠
⁠
+July 30: Form 941, your quarterly reporting of federal income and payroll tax withholdings from employee paychecks.⁠
+July 31: Form 5500 for reporting the status of your company’s retirement savings plans, including condition, investments and participation, to the IRS and Department of Labor. There are different forms for businesses with fewer than 100 employees and those with 100+ employees.⁠
⁠
Keep reading at the link in our bio.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by CO— by USCC on July 20, 2021 tagging @southlacafe. May be an image of 2 people and text.

node.text:
When you invest in your community, your community will invest in your business. ⁠
⁠
That’s the lesson Joe and Celia Ward-Wallace, founders of @southlacafe, learned as they navigated the challenges of being in the restaurant industry during the COVID-19 pandemic.⁠
⁠
When the pandemic hit, South LA Cafe — a Black-owned community coffee shop, market and cultural center located in the heart of Los Angeles — had only been in business for a few months. The cafe originally opened in December 2019 and attained astounding success in a short period of time, with revenue growing by 10% each month.⁠
⁠
Shutdowns forced the cafe to rely solely on takeout orders rather than dine-ins and other face-to-face experiences. Suddenly, revenue dropped by 70% and most of the staff were furloughed.⁠
⁠
The husband-and-wife team said the key to their survival and success was the support they received from their community.⁠
⁠
“[The community] rallied behind us, and over 500 community members sent us financial contributions on a monthly basis to help us stay open,” they said.⁠
⁠
With the backing of its local community, South LA Cafe was able to pivot immediately, delivering meals to seniors, launching an advance-ordering app with curbside pickup and providing prepared South LA Grocery Boxes, which were available for purchase and to “sponsor” to neighbors in need.⁠
⁠
“We also launched our South LA Grocery Giveaway, which has fed over 46,000 people in the past 46 weeks,” said Joe and Celia Ward-Wallace.⁠
⁠
Read more about South LA Café at the link in our bio.⁠
